description: From Middle French, from Old French, from Late Latin orificium (“an opening, literally the making of a mouth”), compound of os (“mouth”) + facio (“to make”).

entries.meaning: A mouth or aperture, such as of a tube, pipe, etc.; an opening.
examples: the orifice of an artery or vein; the orifice of a wound; the vagina and other orifices

entries.meaning: (slang, derogatory) A stupid or objectionable person.
examples: “Peanuts aren't nuts, you orifice. They're legumes.”
